Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modifications of turbulent boundary layer structure by wall permeability and surface-subsurface interactions: an innovative experimental approach

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1236527/1235726
Best/Thurow

Turbulent flows moving over a porous, permeable, surface are ubiquitous in many environmental and industrial flows, such as in rivers, over vegetated canopies, in heat exchangers, membrane tube reactors and hydrocarbon wells. However, despite the widespread importance of these flows in many branches of science, the physics of turbulence across permeable boundaries remains poorly understood, and currently hampers our ability to predict the movement of gases, particles, microbes and pollutants into and out of such surfaces. This project will develop and utilize the latest techniques in optical flow measurement to provide unique new data on the structure of 3D flow above and within permeable surfaces, and critically the interactions between these flows. The project is expected to transform the understanding of surface-subsurface turbulent flow interactions, and enable testing of several key questions concerning the nature of turbulence over such surfaces, and how this flow structure changes as the type of permeable bed is altered and the overlying flow velocity is varied. Laboratory experiments will match the refractive index of the flow and sediment, thus permitting optical measurements to be achieved above and within permeable sediment beds. Additionally, new plenoptic camera techniques will be used for the quantification of three-dimensional flow within a 3D volume, both within and above the permeable surface. The combination of these techniques opens up the possibility of quantitative information that has never been gained before within such complex flows. The project will enable the training of two PhD students in state-of-the-art experimental techniques within a collaborative and interdisciplinary research environment. These unique data will allow development of new conceptual models for flow over permeable surfaces and provide essential data to guide subsequent numerical modelling of these flows. These data will be used to explain how turbulent flows moving over a range of permeable surfaces may be modified by the permeability, and thus examine the fluid dynamic controls on the fate of fine particles moving across the fluid-sediment interface. For instance, these results will be of direct relevance in interpreting the behavior of natural river beds, where gravels can become infilled with fine-grained sediment, and which can control the exchange of nanoparticulates and contaminants between surface and subsurface flows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study investigated the effects of roughness and permeability on the structure of a turbulent boundary layer.  To do so, a plenoptic camera was used to make 3D measurements in a refractive index matched flow facility. The results from this study represent the first extensive application of a plenoptic camera for experimental fluid measurements, as well as the first pairing of a plenoptic camera and a refractive index matched flow facility. A plenoptic camera allows for the entire light field of a scene to be captured, by storing some of the angular information about the rays of light entering the camera. With this added angular information, a scene can be reconstructed into a 3D volume, from a single light-field image. This is very advantageous when making 3D measurements of a flow field as, unlike other 3D techniques, it only requires one camera. This technology has allowed us to study the flow field over highly curved bodies, which produce a complex 3D structures that were previously unseen in 2D studies.

 In the second year of the project, the flow over a single hemispherical roughness element was measured, analogous to the flow of a river over a single river rock. The results from this experiment show a wide variety of 3D structures that are created by the hemisphere, such as large recirculation bubbles and shed arch vortices. Additionally it was found that the high speed flow above the hemisphere sometimes disrupt the recirculation region behind the hemisphere, possibly causing it to travel downstream as a shed arch vortex. The results from this experiment have been accepted for publication in the AIAA journal.

 In the third year of the project, more complex geometries were studied, each selected to better understand the effects of roughness and permeability. Measurements were made of the flow over an impermeable rough bed (an array of hemispheres) and also over permeable rough bed (a matrix of spheres, which allows the fluid to flow in between each element). These geometries are analogous to the flow of a river over and through a river bed.  A more detailed analysis of these measurements is still underway.

 The plenoptic camera is an emerging tool in fluid mechanics. Moreover, the novelty of the camera itself draws attention from expert researchers to young minds with an interest in science. The results from this project never fail turn heads at conferences, laboratory tours, and engineering outreach events.
